query: I'm concerned about an elderly neighbor in Cambridgeshire who seems confused and isn't eating properly. How do I report adult safeguarding concerns?

retrieved_documents.content: Report your concerns about an adult More information about recognising and reporting abuse The Care Act (2014) defines safeguarding as "protecting an adult’s right to live in safety, free from abuse and neglect." Adult safeguarding duties apply to an adult who: has needs for care and support (whether or not the local authority is meeting any of those needs) and is experiencing, or at risk of, abuse and neglect and as a result of their care and support needs, is unable to protect themselves from the risk or experience of abuse and neglect. Guidance and procedures Cambridgeshire and Peterborough Multi Agency Safeguarding Guidance and Procedures helps all agencies to safeguard people with care and support needs and to minimise the risk of harm and/or neglect. Cambridgeshire and Peterborough Safeguarding Adults Board have information on stages of safeguarding, advocacy, protocol for people who self-neglect and protocol for people who display hoarding behaviours

• Take a responsi bility for the protection, safety and welfare of children, young people and adults at 
risk by following the procedures laid down in the Safeguarding and Child Protection Policy 
• Familiarise yourself with the Cambridgeshire and Peterborough Safeguarding Board policies and 
procedures. They can be found at: 
o Children’s : http://www.safeguardingcambspeterbo rough.org.uk/children -board/ 
o Adults at risk: http://www.safeguardingcambspeterborough.org.uk/adults -board/ 
• Maintain the highest standards of professional behaviour and confidentiality when dealing with 
personal and sensitive issues relating to children and adults at risk 
• Be alert to and respond to any suspicions, nagging doubts, serious concerns or allegations or 
disclosures of abuse with regard to the safety and welfare of children or adults at risk and to log or 
record these on the appropriate forms 
• Ensure all adults at r isks are aware of their own health, safety and wellbeing and know what to do;

[Page 4]
 
 
4 | Cambridgeshire County Council – How to give feedback about  Adult Social Care services  Easy Read | June  2024  
 Pictures  Words  
 A complaint is telling Adult Social Care about 
something that is not working well for you.  
 
 
 
 If you want t o raise a complaint, you can:  
• Telephone 0345 045 5202 
• Email 
customercareteam@cambridgeshire.gov.uk  
• Write a letter to the Customer Care Team  (Box 
2116) , PO Box 761, Huntingdon, PE29 9QR 
Or complete the online form here . 
 What happens next? 
 Compliments are forwarded to the Social Care team 
or person it is for .

[Page 5]
 
 
5 | Cambridgeshire County Council – How to give feedback about  Adult Social Care services  Easy Read | June  2024  
 Pictures  Words  
 Comments or suggestions are forwarded to the 
Social Care team for them to action . 
 What happens when you make a complaint?  
 We will write you a letter or an email to tell you that we have got your complaint . 
 We will tell you how long it might take to look at your 
complaint . 
 We will talk  with you and to other people who can 
help with your complaint . 


[Page 6]
 
 
6 | Cambridgeshire County Council – How to give feedback about  Adult Social Care services  Easy Read | June  2024  
 Pictures  Words  
 
 
 We will send you a letter or an email telling you what 
we have done.  
 Giving us feedback or making a complaint will not 
affect how you are treated in the future.  
 What happens if you are still unhappy?  
 You can contact the Local Government and Social 
Care Ombudsman (LGSO).  
 
They are independent of the council.

. There is also support for domestic abuse on the Cambridgeshire Constabulary website . There are Safe Spaces locations for people experiencing domestic abuse in pharmacies and other organisations across the UK. You can ask to use the safe space, where there will be specialist information around getting help. Social care crisis If you are struggling to carry out essential tasks, or are concerned that another adult or older person is unable to look after themselves, please contact us. Contact us Adult services - online contact form Telephone: 0345 045 5202 9am to 5pm, Monday to Friday Outside office hours If someone is in danger and unable to protect themselves, or cannot remain in the community without immediate intervention, telephone: 01733 234 724. In an emergency If you are worried about an adult who is in immediate danger or needs medical treatment contact the police and/or call an ambulance on 999. Food banks Food banks provide emergency food supplies for people in crisis

[Page 4]
 
 
4 | Cambridgeshire County Council – Looking after someone Adult Social Care - Easy Read | Ma rch 2025  
 Pictures  Words  
 
 
 You can find lots more support on our council 
webpages : www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk  
 If you have an accident or become ill, you may not 
be able to help the person you look after.  
 
 
 
 You can register for the What If?  Service.  The 
service can help in emergencies.  
You can find out more at : 
 
https://www.caringtogether.org/support -for-
carers/adult -carers/whatifplan/  
 
 If you need a bit more help, you might be able to get 
some help from the council.  
The council can give you information and advice. 
You can also ask the council for a Carers 
Assessment .

www.safeguardingcambspeterborough.org.uk 
All complaints, disclosures, allegations or suspicions of abuse or any significant concerns about a child or 
adult at risk will be tak en seriously and staff will report to a Designated Person as soon as possible or 
within 24 hours. If the Designated Person is not available, staff should report to a member of the Senior 
Leadership Team. If a crime may have been committed, the concern, sus picion or allegation will be 
reported to the Police. 
Cambridgeshire Skills has a nagging doubt procedure enabling staff members to log concerns regarding the 
welfare of a young person or adult at risk which at that point does not warrant a safeguarding i nvestigation 
(Appendix c). In the event that three nagging doubt concerns are raised in any one academic year, a 
safeguarding concern will be raised to MASH 
The Care Act guidance for the categories of abuse is provided in Appendix d 
Cambridgeshire Skil ls will monitor the quality of its safeguarding revision through :

[Page 3]
 
 
3 | Cambridgeshire County Council – How to give feedback about  Adult Social Care services  Easy Read | June  2024  
 Pictures  Words  
 If you need help to give your feedback, you can ask 
someone to help you.  
 You may want to give us feedback a bout where you 
live. 
 You may want to give us feedback about how you have been treated.  
 You can tell your carers if you are unhappy about something.  
 They may be able to help you.  
 If you feel that you have not been given the service 
you expect, you might want to make a complaint .

. If you are a member of the public Please contact us using the web form or telephone numbers below. Report concerns about an adult - online form Telephone 0345 045 5202 9am to 5pm, Monday to Friday Outside office hours If someone is in danger and unable to protect themselves, or cannot remain in the community without immediate intervention, telephone: 01733 234 724 . In an emergency call 999. For practitioners If you are a Practitioner within CCC you should be using the internal reporting process (ie Mosaic).  If you are unable to do this, or you are an external Practitioner, please use the online referral form for Adults on the Cambridgeshire and Peterborough Safeguarding Adults Board website. Who is an adult at risk? Some adults with care and supports needs may struggle to protect themselves from abuse

. If you are a member of the public Please contact us using the web form or telephone numbers below. Report concerns about an adult - online form Telephone 0345 045 5202 9am to 5pm, Monday to Friday Outside office hours If someone is in danger and unable to protect themselves, or cannot remain in the community without immediate intervention, telephone: 01733 234 724 . In an emergency call 999. For practitioners If you are a Practitioner within CCC you should be using the internal reporting process (ie Mosaic).  If you are unable to do this, or you are an external Practitioner, please use the online referral form for Adults on the Cambridgeshire and Peterborough Safeguarding Adults Board website. Who is an adult at risk? Some adults with care and supports needs may struggle to protect themselves from abuse

answer:
To report adult safeguarding concerns in Cambridgeshire, you can contact the local authorities using the following methods:

- **Online Form**: Use the online form available on the Cambridgeshire County Council website to report concerns about an adult.
- **Telephone**: Call **0345 045 5202** between 9am and 5pm, Monday to Friday.
- **Outside Office Hours**: If the situation is urgent and occurs outside of office hours, call **01733 234 724**.
- **Emergency Situations**: If the adult is in immediate danger or requires medical attention, call **999**.

For more detailed guidance, you can refer to the Cambridgeshire and Peterborough Safeguarding Adults Board's website at [safeguardingcambspeterborough.org.uk/adults-board](http://www.safeguardingcambspeterborough.org.uk/adults-board).

According to the documents, safeguarding involves protecting an adult's right to live in safety, free from abuse and neglect, and applies to adults with care and support needs who are at risk of abuse or neglect.

test_metadata.prompt_template:
Please answer the following question about social care services in UK local authorities based only on the information in the provided documents.

Question: {query}

Context from relevant documents:
{context}

Instructions:
1. Provide a clear, direct answer that would help someone needing this information. If information isn't available, state: "The available documents don't provide specific information about [aspect]."

2. Synthesize information from ALL relevant documents to provide the most complete answer rather than analyzing documents individually.

3. Structure your response with:
   - A concise 1-2 sentence summary first
   - Relevant details organized in short, clear paragraphs
   - Bullet points for lists or step-by-step information
   - Bold text for key information the user should notice

4. For financial information:
   - Include exact figures, time periods, and what the funding covers
   - Present financial data clearly: "The adult social care budget is **£X million** for [time period]"

5. Always include practical next steps or resources:
   - Provide contact information, URLs, or application methods mentioned in the documents
   - Suggest where the person could find more information

6. When citing sources, use a simple format: "According to [document name/description]" or include URLs where available.

Answer:
